title: Advancing Healthcare
description: Building a dynamic content discovery experience with hundreds of creatively animated, interactive dots.

children.value: Building a dynamic content discovery experience with hundreds of creatively animated, interactive dots.

Deerfield is an investment management company with a focus on healthcare - with hundreds of articles on their website for visitors to browse and discover. The challenge that presented itself was how visitors would find content, and how to display it to promote discovery. The user experience had to guide users towards key content, while also keeping it well organized and fluid enough that you could explore in many different ways.

This project entailed taking an agency's design files and working alongside them to develop a reactive component that was visually interesting, while also performing well across a multitude of device capabilities.

As you’d expect, a bunch of math went into place to calculate where each dot would land, and how they animate across the screen. HTML5 canvas was used to render the layer, with hit tests that trigger modal pop-ups surfacing more details on each content item.

Content was drawn to the screen in concentric rings, with each dot representing a single content item. These items were color-coded into one of three categories, and their distance to the center of the diagram
was determine based on the content’s relevance.

This functionality was extended into the search feature. When a user enters a search term, or clicks on one of the three main categories of content, the network will re-arrange and filter itself to show the most appropriate content front-and-center. Search itself was implemented using SwiftType.

On the initial load, we wanted a full introduction animation before the network comes together to form their core values. This process involved not only working to simultaneously load data and swap out pseudo-elements, but a custom SVG filter was developed with some clever trickery to allow the dots to "blob" together when near each other, creative an intriguing fluid effect.

Performance was key, so the experience was extensively tested on a variety of mobile devices. We were constantly checking frame rate, animation speeds, hit boxes, and more to ensure a consistent and enjoyable browsing experience.

The final component provided for a robust and navigable user experience that allowed visitors to quickly find what was relevant to them. By implementing this system, Deerfield has improved the overall user experience for their visitors and increased the discoverability of their content.

props.position: Director of Software Development at White Rhino, Inc

children.value: Building the new look for Vite

Vite is a next-generation build tool that offers a fast and modern development experience, making it a favorite among front-end developers. It's used by many popular frameworks, including React, Angular, Vue, Solid, Svelte, and many others. With over 15 million weekly npm downloads and more than 6 million dependent projects, Vite has become a cornerstone of modern web development, supported by a vibrant community of over 1,000 contributors.

In early 2024, Evan You, the creator of Vue.js and Vite, approached me with an exciting opportunity: he wanted to completely overhaul the Vite homepage to better represent the project's growth and vision. This redesign was also part of a larger initiative tied to the launch of VoidZero, a VC-backed company Evan was starting to take Vite and other projects into the future. This was an incredible chance to contribute to a tool that has become a core part of modern web development.

) featured detailed animations and interactivity that represented the future-facing vision of Vite. Thanks to Vincent's well-organized Figma designs, I was able to work asynchronously. He even fully mocked up the animation sequences, using Figma magic that’s frankly above my pay grade. His work speaks for itself in everything he does.
The project presented a unique challenge. Vite is known for being "
", with a history of obsessive focus on performance, so the website needed to communicate that in its own performance metrics. I wanted to ensure that the page loads immediately and never felt "

" in terms of frame rate or interactivity. Additionally, we had to minimize any dependencies, as they would propagate downstream to all projects using Vite. GSAP was the only new dependency, used for handling complex animations, and added only as a development dependency to avoid it impacting downstream production bundles.

I began by cloning the Vite repo and diving into the VitePress installation for the homepage and docs. This was admittedly one of my earliest projects using VitePress specifically, but it supports Vue components out of the box, making it very easy to work with. My approach was to first establish an initial layout for each section and build the components one by one. Once the structure was in place, I centralized logic into composables to make the code more efficient and organized. I find this iterative approach—getting something up quickly and refining it continuously—produces my best work. I like to tinker and nitpick until I'm happy with what I see.

With the DOM structure ready, my animation strategy was twofold: use CSS for simpler animations and SVG components for more complex ones. I aimed for a responsive approach, wherein desktop interactions trigger hover animations, while mobile used scroll-based viewport triggers.

The main Vite CPU "chip" in the hero animation is a prime example of the CSS-first approach. The reflective highlight effect was achieved with two linear gradients moving at different speeds, paired with rounding, blurring, and a color-dodge blend mode. This technique created an organic, curved look despite using simple rectangular shapes.
The specular edges utilized a Chromium browser quirk to transition between gradients, creating a sense of moving environment lighting. I'm honestly not sure if that's a bug or a feature.
For more intricate animations, like glowing nodes moving along curved paths, I developed a reusable

component. This component accepted props for path, position, and color, rendering an SVG element accordingly. The glowing effect was achieved by shifting a radial gradient along the path and masking it:

props.code:
<template>
  <g>
    <path
      :d="props.path"
      :stroke="`url(#glow_gradient_${pathId})`"
      :mask="`url(#glow_mask_${pathId})`"
      class="svg-path"
    />
    <!-- ... other elements ... -->
    <defs>
      <mask :id="`glow_mask_${pathId}`">
        <path :d="props.path" fill="black" />
        <circle
          :cx="dotPosition.x"
          :cy="dotPosition.y"
          :r="gradientWidth * gradientWidthScaleFactor"
          fill="white"
        />
      </mask>
      <radialGradient
        :id="`glow_gradient_${pathId}`"
        :cx="dotPosition.x"
        :cy="dotPosition.y"
        :r="gradientWidth * gradientWidthScaleFactor"
        gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"
      >
        <!-- ... gradient stops ... -->
      </radialGradient>
    </defs>
  </g>
</template>

children.value: GSAP was then used to animate these props, creating smooth animations that could handle various easing effects and "stick" the SVG dots to the underlying line paths.
Performance was a key focus throughout. The gradient background in the hero section is a great example of my continuous improvement approach.

Initially, I used two colored circles with a large blur filter. Later, I optimized it to a single background gradient for color, combined with a masked radial gradient for lighting, plus a light grain texture to reduce color banding. This significantly improved mobile performance without compromising the visual style.
Mobile optimizations included reducing transparency and heavy effects like backdrop blur, which are resource-intensive. For animations, I used GPU-friendly CSS properties, leveraging

and other CSS tricks to push animations to the GPU, while avoiding repaints by animating only opacity and transform. Every component was thoroughly tested across browsers and screen sizes to ensure optimal performance. If we could squeeze a few milliseconds out of a frame's render time, consider it squeezed.
It was a joy and an honor to work on this project for the Vite community, and I'm happy to say it was well-received at ViteConf 2024. You can visit the new site at
or check out the repo at
. Feel free to explore the site and see the work firsthand. If you’re inspired, consider contributing to the Vite project and becoming part of this thriving community - you won't regret it! 😉

title: Frontend Nation 2024
description: Crafting completely crazy and collectively constructive creative coding concoctions.

children.value: Talk: Crafting completely crazy and collectively constructive creative coding concoctions.
In June 2024 I had the opportunity to speak at
, the largest online frontend event in the world, alongside a bunch of talented frontend developers. My talk was to be titled
"crafting completely crazy and collectively constructive creative coding concoctions"

I was the final speaker on Day 3, closing out the event by delivering a talk that provided no educational value at all, instead opting to inspire and have some fun with the participants in a highly interactive 3D experience running in the browser. Using frontend tools such as
I crafted an immersive factory experience where participants played as rubber duckies driving forklifts in real-time - with the goal of building a new creative landing page hero section.

Who knows where the idea came from, but early on I decided one of the interactive “toys” participants would interact with would be a forklift. I set out to build a proof-of-concept using a forklift 3D model and building a few physics bounding boxes around it. Working with a segmented mesh
(where the lift mesh was not attached to the main body)
animations to both the mesh and physics body to raise/lower the forklift.

An early test included using a pallet and some traffic cones/barricades that could be ran into. If I could control the forklift and successfully move some traffic cones around an empty space, then the rest would just be icing on the cake.

props.alt: Early prototypes of the forklift and sample physics objects

children.value: Once I was happy with the proof-of-concept, I moved onto to implementing this at scale. I approached development with an object-oriented mindset, building TS classes representing base physics toys, props, structures, and rooms. This allowed me to build upon base functionality, such as automatically-generated physics bounding boxes and contact materials. Structuring code this way enabled me to create scenes at scale that would have otherwise taken me significantly longer otherwise.

One of the most impactful decisions I made along the way was to treat this like a video game more than a web experience, pulling from well-known video game development techniques to optimize for performance. Each “room” was divided using a pair of rolling garage doors that acted like airlocks. Once the camera entered the “airlock”, the previous room’s resources were disposed of and the scene got reset back to
. This logic provided for segmentation during development - I could swap between scenes easily, re-order them, and never worry about keeping multiple scene's resources in memory at once.

The red outlines below represents the physics bodies in the scene. Nearly everything in the scene had a physics body for collisions. This image also shows the modular approach to level development, using a grid to build up the floors, ramps and walls.

Excluding structures, over 70+ unique physics props were created for participants to engage with, ranging from the pallets of npm packages and DOM elements of various types/sizes to barricades, speaker cards, railings and more. Each one had it’s own properties and logic, running on top of a parent class with automatic lifecycle management to ensure models, textures and materials were cached and disposed of when needed. Certain props, like storage racks, hooked into this lifecycle to run additional logic, like adding cardboard boxes to the rack’s shelves as separate physics objects.
Although hard to spot during the madness, there were a ton of small details and easter eggs to discover - such as some non-standard css properties and posters with inspirational messages such as “

props.alt: 3D representations of the box object model

children.value: One of my favorite scenes of the entire talk was the fragment shader room. It took a decent bit of manual work to build up a hex grid of colors to play with - and the result of this with 15 forklifts pushing them all over the place was crazy. This was also one of the more intensive rooms resource-wise, as it required more connections for all of the forklift interactivity and more physics bodies to support all the hex codes. This one scene actually uses more "loose" physics parameters to improve on framerate performance, at the expense of accuracy. This led to some weird things happening, but it visually made sense during the madness of this scene.

One of the core messages of the talk was to emphasize that creative coding is a process of exploration - and that making mistakes was a part of that process. I didn't want things to go perfectly, opting instead to have it crash and burn intentionally.

The original ending, shown below, would take the Frontend Nation logo and drop it into place. Doing so would disrupt the landing page below and scatter the elements, and I'd close out on the aforementioned message.

But that didn't quite feel right. Somewhere, admittedly fairly late in planning for the talk, it dawned on me that I might want to store screen-captures of the factory experience along the way. I'd already developed a process early in prototyping to save out image data for the sake of potentially streaming it to attendees, but this seemed like a better fit.

Within a couple of days, I built out a process that captured low-resolution media during the entire talk, and then compiled it in real-time at the end of the talk to build the Frontend Nation logo back in the original 3D scene. It's sort of trippy when you think about - those are screenshots of the current 3D scene, within the 3D scene itself. The result here being a single high-resolution artwork representing the talk in full, emphasizing that the process of building and giving the talk itself is what led to this artwork being generated through exploration.

title: The Engine @ MIT
description: A content-driven infographic showcasing tough tech, displayed on a floor-to-ceiling LED wall at MIT's The Engine in Boston.

children.value: An innovative content-driven artwork for new headquarters of The Engine at MIT
designed to engage audiences both within and beyond the walls of the new space.

The Engine, a Cambridge-based venture fund, was looking for a creative way to showcase the companies and founders that work at their headquarters, as well as the problems that they are solving. I worked alongside Sosolimited to create a content-driven digitally-rendered artwork that would position The Engine and Tough Tech beyond the walls of the new headquarters, and express the transformative significance of the problems being tackled by the founders and their companies. The artwork was designed for a screen measuring 22' high and 11' wide, in the lobby of their new space, with a 4K resolution and dynamic content streaming from multiple sources.

Our challenge was to create an application that highlighted The Engine’s brand and design principles while accepting various types of data input and edge cases, so that the artwork could best represent all of the activities at The Engine.
The application was built using Vue and Electron, with a custom pipeline for rendering

of data to the screen. With a target minimum of 60fps @ 4K and a highly complex visual to render, every graphical element on-screen was scrutinized. Novel methods were developed for attaching HTML5 canvas rendering to Vue’s reactivity system, so that frames would only be drawn when the content needed to animate. We also employed a “LOD”
approach to animation complexity — so that elements had higher resolution when static, and lower resolution when moving.

Data for the visualizations came from multiple sources. Core content such as companies, key themes, and statistics were delivered using GraphQL via Contentful. Real-time feeds such as Twitter and website articles were passed through a custom-built middleware that provided a layer of data conformity and caching, whilst also implementing additional search and filter logic and bypassing CORS restrictions. We also built a Slack bot for a private channel, to monitor the latest news and  articles shared by employees and associate those with the correct companies.

The end product was an innovative and sophisticated content-driven artwork that successfully positioned The Engine and Tough Tech beyond the walls of the new headquarters, and expressed the transformative significance of the problems that founders and their companies are tackling. The application was designed to engage audiences at hosted and public events, the general community, and to investors across the capital stack as well as strategic partners.

The flexibility of the code allowed for faster structural changes, making last-minute tweaks feasible. This project demonstrated Sosolimited's ability to develop advanced, customized solutions in order to achieve the client’s goals, and I was happy to help bring that to life with some creative code.

title: Dodecahedron
description: An experiment in creating a 3D game where you can only interact over API.

children.value: An experiment in creating a 3D game where you can only interact over API.

In this physics-based open-world desktop game you play as a Dodecahedron, a twelve-sided convex polyhedron. The aim of the game is to "level up" by moving your Dodecahedron to the next milestone. The catch? There are no mouse or keyboard controls - you can only interact through API requests. To begin with you can only move a small amount in each direction, by calling a
endpoint. As the game progresses, you unlock additional API endpoints that give you more flexibility in traversing the 3D world, such as
For the sake of having a clean window and installer, I went with Electron to create a desktop application package. The API was created using Express, which ran a
server for API requests from within Electron’s background process. The game itself was programmed using ThreeJS and some Vue for supporting 2D user interface elements.
Within ThreeJS is where most of the fun happened. The first step was to setup an object model representing the player

and getting the convex physics body of that to collide correctly with the concave terrain and other objects. Once that was in place, I used Electron’s IPC communication flow to capture API requests and pipe then through to the renderer, where ThreeJS could listen and apply physics updates accordingly.

The terrain was partly procedural, but with artistic direction provided by an input heightmap. The heightmap file was pixel-mapped in from a PNG file, and then each local area was split into “chunks”, and dynamically loaded at runtime to support large, sprawling landscapes. With this approach, mountains and valleys could be painted in. A LOD (level-of-detail) approach was developed, to only load every n vertices at varying depths from the camera, and to hide terrain behind the camera
to keep overall performance snappy while having a detailed, distant horizon.
In the screenshot above you can see a series of topographical lines on the terrain at each level of

. This was due to the pixel depth of the input file, that could only stretch so far vertically using luminance as a height value. I originally planned to smooth this out procedurally, but actually ended up keeping the effect, as the physics body worked better when the dodecahedron’s flat sides had levels of flat ground to collide with. This is similar to why I went with a dodecahedron in the first place, and not a sphere - to have the object’s natural shape resist continued motion, making it more challenging to get around.
While I had no real avenue to distribute the game
(it wouldn’t be able to compete with games made with Unity or Unreal Engine, for example)

I wanted to experiment with the idea and perhaps use it as a teaching tool in the future, or as a proof-of-concept for interacting with a self-hosted API server within an Electron app. Several of the creative techniques developed for Dodecahedron have been utilized in recent commercial projects since putting it down.

title: Experience ABM
description: Building a 3D experience with interactive hotspots for ABM's tradeshows and digital marketing endeavors.

children.value: Building a 3D experience with interactive hotspots for ABM's tradeshows and digital marketing endeavors.

ABM builds solutions to keep distribution running smoothly. White Rhino and myself were asked to put together a 3D experience showing their wide range of services, that provided for interaction and intrigue, and to make sure it could be deployed on tablet devices for an upcoming tradeshow.

Experience ABM was an interesting project from the start due to the time crunch of needing to get this live before a tradeshow, and the limitations of needing it to work on tablet devices. While the White Rhino team worked on the CodeIgniter backend and setting up the 2D interface elements, I got to work developing a webGL 3D experience that the user could navigate through by clicking on relevant hotspots.

Each hotspot focuses on an area of improvement that ABM helps companies achieve within their distribution centers, and when clicked would trigger additional information about that particular service. The hotspots were built as 3D elements in the scene, allowing them to be occluded by geometry. A raycaster from the camera determined hover events, whereas they triggered modal counterparts in the regular DOM when clicked.

The experience used Three.js and custom-built GLTF models for each scene. I implemented dynamic camera positioning logic with smooth animations from hotspot-to-hotspot using GSAP, plus a full render engine to correctly light the scene and provide for realistic shadows, ambient occlusion, and global illumination. Soft-shadows and tone mapping helped to sell a level of realism that would otherwise be difficult to achieve in real-time.

A significant amount of work went into performance enhancements, treading the fine line between a photorealistic scene and one that renders quickly across multiple devices - especially as the primary deployment was on touchscreen kiosks at a tradeshow with less-than-optimal GPUs. The end product was a high-performing touchscreen experience that was cross-browser and cross-device friendly, and optimized for their digital marketing efforts with built-in lead capture forms and calls-to-action.

To ensure we provided compatibility with older devices, we ultimately made 2D variations of each scene using a draggable environment mapped onto the inside of a sphere. This also helped at the tradeshow where mobile data was particularly slow; as significantly less data needed to be downloaded before the experience could run.

Configuration of the software was simplified into a repeatable process, with a folder structure that ensured all 3D models/textures were available to the front-end, and XML files used to determine hotspot positioning, copy, icons, etc. The front-end code ingested these files and dynamically rendered the scene from them, so that less had to be hard-coded for each scene.

title: Illuminations by MIT
description: An open-source interactive lighting installation powered by creative coding.

children.value: An open-source interactive lighting installation powered by creative coding.

MIT Illuminations is an ongoing experiment in creative computation at the MIT Welcome Center. The lights dynamically illuminating the center are, like the MIT community, colorful, ever-changing, and alive. They were inspired by a long history of the MIT community deploying creative installations of colorful lights in dormitories, on bridges and buildings, and around campus.
My role in the project was to build a desktop application that could communicate with the lights over UDP

and make programming new shows a breeze for those learning and exploring creative coding. I worked to streamline portions of the user interface, incorporate an audio API that allows of audio input when creating shows, and overhauled the logic under-the-hood in terms of how P5.js operates within the context of the application.

props.alt: The MIT Welcome Center in Boston

children.value: Over time this role expanded to building an open source version of the application that also supported sending lighting data to an Arduino, using a serial port connection. This open source version had to support both Windows and Mac, and have extensive error handling built in, validating user-defined P5.js code as it’s written and providing contextual hints and support.

With that came the need for more extensive settings, allowing the application to be used in many contexts, with and without lights physically connected. Using Electron made deploying and updating the package on end-user machines streamlined, although serious configuration considerations had to be made to support the native serial port bindings.

title: Project Constellation
description: The ideal sales framework for sharing simplified workflows and solutions across a wide network of service offerings.

children.value: The ideal sales framework for sharing simplified workflows and solutions across a wide network of service offerings.

In 2020 I was part of a creative development project that built a prototype web experience to support consultative and customer-centric conversations between a business and its customers. The prototype was designed to unify the business story across horizontals and verticals and to allow salespeople to explore real business challenges that their customers were facing.

The goal of the prototype was to create a visual map of the business ecosystem that would convey its power and impact on businesses that use it. This visual, interactive combined workflow mapper and solution playbook was designed to be dynamic and to grow with the expanding catalog of service offerings and target markets.

It featured fluid level-based navigation to easily handle non-linear conversations and paths, zooming and flying in through various workflows - facilitating exploration. It was designed to connect the dots on all service offerings available, even if they weren't immediately related to the customer's current needs. This was intended to solve a problem of lack of awareness when it came to the client’s expanded offerings, opening the door to extended conversations that focused on more than just what they needed “right now”. It used spatial organization to reveal connections based on customer profile, challenges, industry, market, interests and promotional initiatives. Finally, it easily surfaced applicable case studies and product demos when getting down to the solution level.

My role on the project was lead creative developer, handling the architecture and visual representation of the “graph” system. The application was built in Vue for browser-based usage duration presentational meetings. The development process took place in several sprints, from concepting/prototyping to design treatments and production development. I had the pleasure of working alongside Sosolimited in Boston to bring this one to life.

The frontend was a Vue application, with a major dividing line structurally between the main "graph" experience and the supporting UI chrome, allowing for a separation of concerns between multiple developers without constant merge conflicts. The backend was built with Express, with the goal of providing a simple and stable JSON API in front of a content management system
. The devOps for staging and testing ran on Heroku.

Within the Vue application, I built a workflow system that used a virtual 2D camera and calculated for various levels of 3D depth and focal points alongside art-directable offsets. Additionally, I built automatic diagramming that drew connection lines between associated nodes and animated them on, adding arrow heads and understanding the context of each target node’s anchor point. Lastly, I attached local assets that matched up with a database so that users could select any one of the available assets within the tool, including icons, PDFs, case studies, demo videos and more.
